instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3332: What is 820-3332? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.ISL6259: What is ISL6259? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2010 through 2015.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Short to ground on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: No liquid damage, originally was having troubles turning on and was producing a clicking sound, now the clicking has stopped and the short appeared, still getting orange light, <SIGNAL>PPV5_S5</SIGNAL> is 1.1v not sure what to do now. I created this new thread since it's a new issue than the original posted

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Short to ground on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: First check all other coils for short to GND. I bet a high side FET has shorted on CPU or GPU power supply.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Short to ground on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Yeah, so I'm also getting short to grounds on <SIGNAL>PPDDR_S3_REG</SIGNAL>, PPCPUVCCIO_S0_REG_R, <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0</SIGNAL>, and <SIGNAL>PPVCCSA_S0_REG_R</SIGNAL>, but some of them are low voltage, so I don't know if that's normal, I'm also not familiar with what a FET being low side and high side means.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Short to ground on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
A short on PPDDR is not good. How low is resistance to GND on that bus? 
Look at <TRANSISTOR>Q7330</TRANSISTOR> it's a dual FET. The top one is the high side, it runs from the "full" PPBUS power to the "low" voltage output. If it shorts there is a direct connection from the 12.6v PPBUS to the RAM.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Short to ground on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: So that's neat, going back to test, <SIGNAL>PPDDR_S3_REG</SIGNAL> is now getting ~330ohms resistance to ground when before I was definatly near 0, but pppchvccio_s0_reg is 24ohms to ground, PPCPUVCCIO_S0_REG_R is 16ohms, <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0</SIGNAL> is 4ohms, and <SIGNAL>PPVCCSA_S0_REG_R</SIGNAL> is 11ohms. Q73330 looks right as rain

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Short to ground on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
So you have no "full" short on any coils, that is good at least.
What is resistance on PPBUS though? If it matches any of the coils you measured you probably have a shorted high side FET on that bus.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Short to ground on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Resistance on PPBUS is around 4ohms, which matches the resistance on the <SIGNAL>CPUIMVP_PHASE</SIGNAL>* busses which would lead me to believe that its the MAX15119GTM, but it's not producing any heat. So then I went around with my laser temperature gun, narrowing down with evaporating alcohol to find ISL6259HRTZ is hot as shit meaning that's it's the thing shorting to ground, but would this also cause the <SIGNAL>CPUIMVP_PHASE</SIGNAL>* stuff to do so as well, and would this chip have been able to make the clicking sounds?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Short to ground on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Measure from PPBUS to <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0</SIGNAL> and see if resistance is 0, then you know you have a shorted high side FET on that bus. The 6259 is probably dead too, but need to check PPVCORE first.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Short to ground on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Alright, sorry for taking so long, I finally got in a bunch of different donor boards which I needed.

So I started off replacing the <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> as well as <CAPACITOR>C7040</CAPACITOR> since it didn't look happy, and then replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q7035</TRANSISTOR> since it was causing a short to common on <SIGNAL>CHGR_LGATE</SIGNAL>
 
I did test the resistance between <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>VCORE_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>, and got ~4ohm resistance, and resistance with PPBUS to common is ~3ohms, is this about right?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Short to ground on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: 3 ohms to GND on PPBUS is a short of course. Time to inject voltage and see what heats up. Start off low with 2V and monitor current.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Short to ground on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: I don't have a power supply, is there a different efficient way of snuffing out a short

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Short to ground on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: A dead motherboard that still powers on. Use the CPU Vcore power supply to get a 1V high current power supply.
